mainmatter.p: Let \mathcal{V} be a universe. A poset D is a \mathcal{V}-dcpo if the join of of every \mathcal{V}-family on set D exists in D.

ul.li: From Definition 3.2.7 of Tom de Jong's PhD thesis

mainmatter.p: A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is called algebraic if the type \mathsf{KK} _{ x } \is

A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is structurally continuous if for every x : D, we have a specified directed \mathcal{V}-family (I, \alpha ) satisfying the following conditions.
(I, \alpha ) is a directed family.
x is the supremum of (I, \alpha ).
Every \alpha (i) given by (I, \alpha ) is way below x.
Definition 4.4.1 of Tom de Jong's PhD thesis.
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo is algebraic if the propositional truncation of its structural algebraicity holds.
Definition 4.6.3 of Tom de Jong's PhD thesis.

frontmatter.title: Small basis (of algebraicity) for a dcpo

mainmatter.p: Adapted from Definition 4.6.7 of Tom de Jong's PhD thesis.

A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is called structurally algebraic if for every x : D we have a specified I : \mathcal{V} and directed compact family \kappa : I \to D such that \kappa has supremum x and each element \kappa (i) is compact.
Definition 4.6.1 of Tom de Jong's PhD thesis.

ul.li: From Definition 3.2.7 of Tom de Jong's PhD thesis

frontmatter.title: Note on order theory terminology in UF

mainmatter.p: In this note, I briefly summarize some discussions that I (Ayberk Tosun) have had with Tom de Jong and Martín Escardó and present my proposal for changes to terminology in order theory in univalent

Similar terminology is used in
the work de Jong and Escardó on order theory in univalent foundations; and
the work of Tosun and Escardó on locale theory in univalent foundations.
Let us first review the two most fundamental notions in the aforementioned lines of research respectively.
In de Jong's thesis, we have the notion of a \mathcal{V}-dcpo.
Let \mathcal{V} be a universe. A poset D is a \mathcal{V}-dcpo if the join of of every \mathcal{V}-family on set D exists in D.

ul.li: From Definition 3.2.7 of Tom de Jong's PhD thesis

mainmatter.p: Whereas in the MFPS paper of Tosun and Escardó, we have the notion of a ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-frame.

A ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-frame L consists of a
a type |L| : \mathcal{U}
a partial order - \le - : |L| \to |L| \to \Omega _{ \mathcal{V} },
a top element \mathbf{1} : |L|,
an operation - \wedge - : |L| \to |L| \to |L| giving the greatest lower bound U \wedge V of any two U, V : |L|.
an operation \bigvee - : \mathsf{Fam} _{ \mathcal{W} }(|L|) \to |L| giving the least upper bound \bigvee _{i : I} U_i of any \mathcal{W}-family \left \{ U_i \right \} _{i : I}.
such that binary meets distribute over arbitrary joins, i.e. U \wedge \bigvee _{i : I} V_i = \bigvee _{i : I} U \wedge V_i for every U : |L| and \mathcal{W}-family \{ V_i \} _{i : I} in |L|.
Definition 2.4 from Patch Locale of a Spectral Locale in Univalent Type Theory.
Most locales that come up in practice are defined by ( \mathcal{U} ^+, \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{U} )-frames, so this much generality is rarely needed. Such locales are called large and locally small.
A locale X is called large and locally small if it is given by a ( \mathcal{U} ^+, \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{U} )-frame.
Central to our work with Martín is the notion of a spectral locale. In impredicative foundations of mathematics, this notion is defined as in the following.
In both domain theory and locale theory, some notion of basis is needed. In our previous work with Martín on locale theory, we used the following notion of small basis.

frontmatter.title: Small basis for a (U, V, W)-locale

mainmatter.p:
Let X be a ( \mathcal{U} , \mathcal{V} , \mathcal{W} )-locale. A basis for X is a \mathcal{W}-family (B, \beta ) on \mathcal{O} ( X ) satisfying the following conditions.
For every open U : \mathcal{O} ( X ), there is a \mathcal{W}-family (K_U, \kappa _U) on the basis index B, satisfying U = \bigvee _{k : K_U} \beta ( \kappa _U(k)).
Each family (K_U, \kappa _U), whose existence is stipulated by the previous condition, is also directed.

Our experience has shown, however, that it might not have been correct to call this notion “basis”. The problem is that there is a nontrivial structure involved in this definition: the index set B of the basis. Under certain favourable conditions the basis of a locale (or resp. dcpo) is uniquely determined. Because of this nontrivial structure, however, this does not work in our case.

Proposed change 1. Rename what we have been calling “small basis” so far to “basis description”.
The idea is that there might be two different descriptions for the same basis, and it is not surprising that these are not the same. This is completely natural. The reason it seems surprising is that we called the wrong thing “basis”.

A \mathcal{V}-dcpo D is structurally continuous if for every x : D, we have a specified directed \mathcal{V}-family (I, \alpha ) satisfying the following conditions.
(I, \alpha ) is a directed family.
x is the supremum of (I, \alpha ).
Every \alpha (i) given by (I, \alpha ) is way below x.
Definition 4.4.1 of Tom de Jong's PhD thesis.
A \mathcal{V}-dcpo is algebraic if the propositional truncation of its structural algebraicity holds.
Definition 4.6.3 of Tom de Jong's PhD thesis.
